descript.abstract:
Metropolitan Police Department (MPD) districts. This dataset contains polygons representing MPD police districts. It was created as part of the DC Geographic Information System (DC GIS) for the D.C. Office of the Chief Technology Officer (OCTO) and participating D.C. government agencies. Police jurisdictions were created by selecting street arcs from the WGIS planimetric street centerlines and, where necessary, heads-up digitized from the snapbase.
All DC GIS data is stored and exported in Maryland State Plane coordinates NAD 83 meters.
METADATA CONTENT IS IN PROCESS OF VALIDATION AND SUBJECT TO CHANGE.
descript.purpose: This data is used for the planning and management of Washington, D.C. by local government agencies.

idinfo.accconst: Contact OCTO GIS. Any data obtained outside of OCTO GIS are unauthorized copies.

procstep.procdesc:
The following reference materials were used to create the new Police Service Area (PSA) layer:
Snapbase from 06/13/2003 assembled from the following source layers: o DCBNDY o RAIL o SIS_SCL o SMD2002 o ANC2002 o VOTEPRE2002 o WATER o ZIP Citywide_31204 shapefile supplied by MPD roughly outlining the new PSAs. Text description report defining the boundaries of every PSA supplied by MPD. Current (old) version of the PSA on the OCTO Geodatabase. 1999 DC orthophotograph.
Procedures:
1. The reference materials were assembled in the ArcView 3.3 environment. The prj file defined the projection in which arcs were selected to define the PSAs.
2. A copy of the snapbase was modified with a new integer field, called newpsa. When arcs that make up the new PSAs were selected, the records were tagged with a value of 1 in the new field while the rest of the unselected records were tagged as 0.
3. For arcs that required spatial modifications like splitting, snapping, or drawing in new segments, a hard copy print out of the Citywide_31204 shapefile was marked up to identify the areas that required change. These changes were made in the arcedit environment later on in the process to maintain precision.
4. Within the arcedit environment, an analyst used arctools to zoom into the identified areas from the hardcopy printout and draw, intersect, or snap the necessary segments. Then the modified arcs or new arcs were attributed with 1 in the newpsa field.
5. After all the segments that comprise the PSAs were completed, the analyst selected all the arcs with a value of 1 in the newpsa and placed into a new coverage. This new coverage was used to QC the selections if there were any segments missing to enclose polygons or self intersecting arcs. Staff performed a build on the coverage to identify arcs with topological errors.
6. The snapbase was then modified to fix the errors identified in step 5.
7. Once all errors were fixed, all the arcs with the value of 1 were then reselected and put into a new coverage for building the PSA polygons.
8. Within the ArcView 3.3 environment, the City_31204 shapefile was used to create centroids and an additional integer field was added for calculating the PSA coverage ID though a spatial join (point to polygon).
9. The PSA coverage attribute table was then populated with the PSA ID by performing a table join with the centroid attribute table where the polygon ID matched the ID that was calculated in step 8.
10. Staff then saved the changes and the process is completed.
11. From the PSA coverage, staff dissolved on district-id to generate the police districts.
Planimetrics were created at a scale of 1:1,000. This means that a well defined feature falls within two feet of true position.
All DC GIS data is stored and exported in Maryland State Plane coordinates NAD 83 meters.
